definitions.definition: to get rid of something that is no longer wanted

examples.text: The factory is shedding a large number of jobs.
a quick way to shed unwanted pounds *(= extra weight or fat on your body)*
Museums have been trying hard to shed their stuffy image.
She was determined to shed some weight and get fit.
The firm is trying to shed its old-fashioned image.
Her mother had shed ten years since her marriage to Douglas.

definitions.definition: to take off a piece of clothing

examples.text: Luke shed his clothes onto the floor.

definitions.definition: to lose or drop what it is carrying

examples.text: The traffic jam was caused by a lorry **shedding its load**.

definitions.definition: if an animal sheds its skin, or a plant sheds leaves, it loses them naturally

examples.text: How often does a snake shed its skin?
trees that shed their leaves in autumn

definitions.definition: to send light over something; to let light fall somewhere

examples.text: The candles shed a soft glow on her face.
She shed no tears when she heard he was dead.

definitions.definition: to kill or injure people, especially in a war

examples.text: How much blood will be shed before the fighting ends?

definitions.definition: to have the quality of causing water or liquid to run off and not sink in

examples.text: A duck's feathers shed water immediately.

definitions.definition: to make a problem, etc. easier to understand

examples.text: Recent research has shed new light on the causes of the disease.

wordOrigin: verb Old English sc(e)ādan ‘separate out (one selected group), divide’, also ‘scatter’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch and German scheiden. Compare with sheath.
